ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Great! The organization of the class facilitates the learning of the healthcare system well.
I learned to read primary and secondary medical history sources and discuss it in a small section setting.
Understanding of how racism and stigma pervaded healthcare throughout the 20th century.
I learned a great deal about the history of the medical field and how the healthcare system became a commodity.
The range of topics on healthcare in general, Medicare and Medicaid, public health programs, and so on was really valuable.

I learned a lot about how to do historical research and writing which was very helpful. I also learned so much about the context and application of healthcare in the US and how we got to where we are now which I'm very interested in. We also heard a fair amount about hospitals and healthcare in New Haven from Professor Abedin which was really cool!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The section discussion was really well read, maybe a little more guidance on the final paper would be helpful (a writing workshop perhaps?)

Strengths: Prof. Abedin is incredibly knowledgable and absolutely lovely, the weekly discussion questions were really helpful in approaching readings critically, syllabus is well crafted and structured to facilitate learning, the feedback from my first paper was actually really helpful in writing my second paper

Weaknesses: 9:25AM discussions were often lagging and I feel like people often were not paying attention to the weekly presentations, would have enjoyed more primary source engagement within the weekly readings
The readings are really interesting, but it felt somewhat that we had the same conversation every week, so maybe more variety in the themes.

This class had one of the most interesting selections of readings Ive had in a course. I always felt like I had something I could contribute in section. Sometimes I felt a little behind in the course if I had other work competing with it, which was hard. I wish the class could have been a little more flexible.

This class was really good! I thought the readings overall were very interesting and our discussions felt very balanced. I also really liked that there were both primary and secondary sources for our readings so we got to see both. I did think some of the units felt a little repetitive but they built on each other so it was okay.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Interesting, engaging, and not too stressful

Yes! I think any public health knowledge is essential for any responsible pre-med student! You get to understand the race relations and inequity to healthcare that many people do not talk about enough.
Yes! Great class if you are interested in healthcare or health policy and Prof. Abedin is fantastic
Yes! I learned so much about the healthcare system. And the class discussions are very engaging.
Yes, it was a bit of work but worth it to engage with really important topics.
I would! I thought it was a very good introduction to healthcare in the US and the ways it does not meet the needs of many people.

extras.title: HIST 150J 02/HSHM 406 02 - Healthcare for the Urban Poor
